Description: Rim sherd of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim and part of handle root; interior: reserved band at top of lip, glazed black (fired red) below; top of lip glazed; exterior: lip and handle zone reserved, with black band between; glazed below; black around handle root.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (possibly)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Ure Museum of Greek Archaeology, Reading. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this cup, the type possibly belongs to his Type 9B South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 9B cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. For parallels regarding the shape, see British Museum 1886,0401.219.
Bibliographic references: CVA Reading I / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain, Fasc. 12, University of Reading (p. 33, pl. 21, no. 8a-b)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.574) (Phase 3)
